Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Situation2: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my sister’s excited message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, tonight’s the big celebration! I can’t wait to see you!” She’d just landed her dream job, and our family was gathering to celebrate her achievement. As her sister, I knew how much this meant to her—and to me. We’d always promised to be there for each other’s milestones, no matter what.

But as I set my phone down, my work phone buzzed. The court clerk’s voice was brisk: “Officer, you’re required to testify in court tomorrow morning. Please review your notes and be prepared.” I felt my stomach twist. As a police officer, I was expected to act with integrity, to uphold the law, and to never shirk my duty—especially not when a case depended on my testimony.

The two worlds collided in my mind. My sister’s shining face, her trust in me to show up. The weight of my badge, the oath I’d taken. I could feel the pressure mounting, the expectations pulling me in opposite directions. I sat in silence, torn, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left behind.
